title: Blood and Bourbon
description: The year is 1925. Vincent 'Vinnie' Morelli, owner of the Blue Moon Speakeasy, has been found dead in his private office. As Detective Sam Hawthorne, you must navigate the shadowy world of bootleggers, jazz musicians, and dangerous secrets to find the killer.

setting.background: Prohibition is in full swing. The Blue Moon is one of Chicago's most exclusive underground establishments, hidden beneath Rosetti's Bakery. Tonight was supposed to be a celebration - Vinnie had just secured a major liquor deal with the Canadian suppliers.

victim.name: Vincent 'Vinnie' Morelli
victim.description: Charismatic speakeasy owner with connections to Chicago's underworld. Known for his expensive suits and gold pocket watch.
secretsRevealed: Was planning to cut ties with the Chicago mob and go legitimate
Had been skimming money from his business partner, Tony Romano
Was having an affair with Ruby Diamond, the jazz singer
victim.causeOfDeath: Poisoned with cyanide in his private bourbon

locations.name: Vinnie's Private Office
locations.description: A luxurious office behind the main speakeasy. Heavy oak desk, leather chairs, and a private bar. Vinnie's body slumps in his chair, a glass of bourbon beside him.

locations.name: Main Speakeasy Floor
locations.description: The heart of the Blue Moon. Jazz band stage, bar, scattered tables. The air is thick with cigarette smoke and nervous energy.

locations.name: Backstage Dressing Room
locations.description: Where performers prepare. Mirrors, costumes, and makeup scattered about. Ruby's corner is notably luxurious.

locations.name: Storage Room
locations.description: Where the illegal liquor is kept. Crates of Canadian whiskey, bottles of gin, and accounting ledgers.

locations.name: Speakeasy Kitchen
locations.description: A small kitchen for preparing basic food. More importantly, it's where drinks are prepared before serving.

locations.name: Back Alley Entrance
locations.description: The discrete entrance to the speakeasy. Dark, narrow, with a hidden door behind stacked crates.

evidence.name: Vinnie's Body
evidence.description: Vinnie sits slumped in his chair, foam at his lips. Smells faintly of bitter almonds - classic sign of cyanide.
evidence.revealsClue: Cyanide poisoning occurred 10-15 minutes before discovery
evidence.forensicDetail: No signs of struggle; he was comfortable with his killer

evidence.name: Bourbon Glass
evidence.description: Vinnie's personal crystal tumbler, half-empty. His private bottle sits nearby.
evidence.revealsClue: Only Vinnie's fingerprints on the glass, but fresh prints on the bottle
evidence.forensicDetail: Cyanide was added to the bottle, not the glass

evidence.name: Threatening Note
evidence.description: A typed note: 'PAY UP OR PAY THE PRICE - TONIGHT'
evidence.revealsClue: Typewriter analysis matches the one in the storage room

evidence.name: Love Letter to Ruby
evidence.description: Passionate letter from 'R.M.' begging Ruby to run away together.
evidence.revealsClue: Not Vinnie's handwriting; signed 'R.M.' - Robert Miller, a traveling salesman

evidence.name: Liquor Shipping Manifest
evidence.description: Latest shipment records showing discrepancies in inventory.
evidence.revealsClue: Someone's been skimming - bottles missing from each shipment
evidence.forensicDetail: Vinnie's notes in margins show he discovered the theft

evidence.name: Cyanide Bottle
evidence.description: Small bottle labeled 'Rat Poison' hidden behind spices. Nearly empty.
evidence.revealsClue: Fresh fingerprints belong to Margaret Sinclair
evidence.forensicDetail: Purchased from Rosetti's Hardware - they keep records

evidence.name: Bourbon Bottle with Prints
evidence.description: Vinnie's private bottle of bourbon. Someone handled it recently.
evidence.revealsClue: Margaret's fingerprints on the bottle neck
evidence.forensicDetail: Prints are fresh - within the last hour

evidence.name: Lipstick-Stained Cigarette
evidence.description: Turkish cigarette with expensive lipstick. Still warm.
evidence.revealsClue: Margaret's brand and lipstick shade - she was outside at 10:35 PM
evidence.forensicDetail: Expensive Turkish tobacco only she smokes

evidence.name: Bruno's Statement
evidence.description: The doorman saw Margaret leave through the alley at 10:35 PM, looking 'rattled'
evidence.revealsClue: Contradicts her alibi of being in the ladies' lounge
evidence.forensicDetail: Bruno has no reason to lie; he's worked here for years

evidence.name: Bar Service Schedule
evidence.description: Shows Charlie was scheduled for bar duty all night, no breaks.
evidence.revealsClue: Charlie often takes unauthorized breaks when busy

evidence.name: Ruby's Stage Costume
evidence.description: Her costume from tonight's performance, still damp with perspiration.
evidence.revealsClue: She definitely performed, but costume suggests shorter set than claimed
evidence.forensicDetail: Not sweaty enough for a 30-minute performance

evidence.name: Kitchen Access Log
evidence.description: Log showing who entered the kitchen. Margaret signed in at 10:25 PM.
evidence.revealsClue: Margaret was in the kitchen just before Vinnie's death

evidence.name: Various Patron Statements
evidence.description: Multiple patrons confirm seeing suspects at various times, with contradictions.
evidence.revealsClue: No one can verify Margaret's whereabouts from 10:15-10:45 PM
evidence.forensicDetail: All other suspects have at least partial verification

timeline.event: Eddie starts his piano set; Tony begins poker game
Ruby begins her performance; Margaret claims to feel ill
Tony briefly leaves poker table (Eddie too drunk to notice)
Ruby ends her set early; Margaret enters kitchen, signs log
Margaret poisons Vinnie's bourbon bottle in his office
Vinnie pours his nightly bourbon; Eddie takes his break; Charlie briefly leaves bar
Bruno sees Margaret exit through alley, looking rattled
Tony returns to poker game; Vinnie dies from cyanide
Ruby claims her set ended (lie); Margaret returns to main room
Charlie discovers Vinnie's body while bringing him receipts
Police arrive; Detective Hawthorne begins investigation

solution.method: Poisoned Vinnie's private bourbon bottle with cyanide
solution.motive: Vinnie discovered she was Federal Agent Mary Sullivan. He threatened to expose her, which would ruin her investigation and endanger her sick daughter who needs expensive treatment.
solution.explanation: Margaret learned that Vinnie had discovered her true identity. Desperate to protect her cover and her daughter, she signed into the kitchen at 10:25 PM, took the cyanide, went to Vinnie's office while he was out, and poisoned his private bourbon bottle. She knew his habits - he always had a drink at 10:30 PM. She then fled through the alley, where Bruno saw her. The federal agent killed to protect a greater good, but murder is still murder.

redHerrings.falseClue: The threatening note seemed to implicate Eddie due to his debts
redHerrings.resolution: Eddie owed money but was too cowardly to kill; he was genuinely playing piano

redHerrings.falseClue: Her affair, criminal past, and the love letter made her look guilty
redHerrings.resolution: The love letter was from someone else; she had already stolen what she wanted

redHerrings.falseClue: His discovery of the skimming and mob connections made him suspicious
redHerrings.resolution: Despite his anger, Tony loved Vinnie like a brother and couldn't kill him

challenge.primaryGoal: Identify Margaret Sinclair as the murderer
subGoals: Discover Margaret's true identity as a federal agent
Find evidence placing her in the kitchen and office
Break her alibi with Bruno's testimony

characters.greeting: Yeah? What's a dick doin' in my joint? If this is about Vinnie... *clenches fist* ...you better find who did this.
characters.systemPrompt: You are Tony Romano, a tough Chicago bootlegger in 1925. You speak in a gruff manner, dropping g's from -ing words (talkin', thinkin'). You're genuinely devastated about Vinnie's death - he was like a brother to you, even though you recently discovered he was stealing. You're angry and hurt, but would never have killed him. You use period slang like 'jake' (good), 'dick' (detective), 'scratch' (money). When pressed, you get emotional about your shared history growing up on the streets together.

characters.greeting: *Exhales cigarette smoke* Well, well... a detective. I suppose you're here about poor Vinnie. *touches your arm* Such a terrible thing, sugar.
characters.systemPrompt: You are Ruby Diamond, a sultry jazz singer in a 1920s speakeasy. You speak with confidence and use period slang like 'sugar,' 'doll,' 'the bee's knees.' You often deflect serious questions with flirtation. You were having an affair with Vinnie but were planning to leave him. You're terrified your criminal past (as Ruth Goldberg) will be exposed. When cornered, you become vulnerable and may cry, but you're always calculating your next move. You did NOT kill Vinnie, despite having reasons to want him gone.

characters.greeting: Oh! Detective! I was just... I mean, terrible thing about Vinnie, just terrible. *fidgets with cufflinks* I've been playing all night, ask anyone!
characters.systemPrompt: You are Eddie 'Fingers' McGraw, a piano player with a gambling addiction in 1925. You speak quickly, often making musical references ('that doesn't strike the right chord,' 'let me give you the key'). You stammer when lying: 'I was... I mean... that is to say...' You're desperate about your $5,000 debt to Vinnie but you didn't kill him. You're terrified of being blamed. When pressed, you admit to your debts and become increasingly frantic, but you're essentially harmless - just a man in over his head.

characters.greeting: Good evening, Detective. *adjusts pearl necklace* This is all quite shocking. Vincent was such a... colorful character.
characters.systemPrompt: You are Margaret Sinclair, actually Federal Agent Mary Sullivan undercover in 1925. You maintain an upper-class facade, speaking formally and properly. However, under extreme pressure, you occasionally slip into a working-class Chicago accent. You killed Vinnie because he discovered your identity and threatened to expose you, which would endanger your sick daughter. You're calculating and careful, sticking to your alibi about being in the ladies' lounge. You deflect suspicion by pointing out others' motives. You feel justified in your actions - Vinnie was a criminal who threatened your child.

characters.greeting: Detective. *polishes glass* In my line of work, you see everything and say nothing. But tonight... tonight's different.
characters.systemPrompt: You are Charlie Hayes, a philosophical bartender in a 1920s speakeasy. You speak in measured tones, often using bartender metaphors ('Truth is like good whiskey - it burns going down'). You're actually Vinnie's half-brother, but few know this. You're protective of the staff, especially Ruby, and you observe everything. You didn't kill Vinnie, but you're not sorry he's dead. When questioned, you deflect by revealing others' secrets, playing the role of the wise observer who knows more than he says.
